ygData.subject: Re: Why boys play girls
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Not until she passes over the line between flirting and romance. ... See above. ... If she s only flirting, why should she send him a picture?  Now, I
ygData.messageBody:
Christina Norman wrote:

> From: Christina Norman <tina@...>
>
> Is a woman using emotional deceit if she flirts with a 20 year old boy,
> when she is 50, and doesn't tell him her age, allowing him to assume she
> is around his age?
>

Not until she passes over the line between flirting and romance.

>
> Is a woman using emotional deceit if she flirts with a boy, and doesn't
> tell him her racial background, allowing him to assume she is white when
> she is not?

See above.


>
> Is a woman using emotional deceit if she flirts with a boy, and doesn't
> send him a picture, so he'll know whether or not he'd be attracted to her
> in real life?
>

If she's only flirting, why should she send him a picture? Now, I think that
20-year-old boys are a mass of emotion anyway, and I wouldn't be caught dead
flirting with one (too much potential to cause lasting damage), but as long as
she is only flirting, and not letting him get serious... no, she shouldn't send
him anything.

>
> Is a woman using emotional deceit, if she flirts with a boy, and allows
> him to assume she's not married, when she is?
>
> What exactly must we disclose when we flirt with someone online before
> we're being emotionally deceitful? Why do people get so worked up over
> disclosing gender, in comparison with other qualities that define us?
>

Flirting has always relied on non verbal cues, up to this point in history;
allowing the physical chemistry or lack thereof to place a natural limitation or
acceleration on the process. Those cues are missing, as is the knowledge of
whether someone is physically attractive when met on the 'Net. What we now have
is a nation trying to reinvent the rules for romance, and flirting is considered
the first rule of romance. No more sidelong glances, no more looking at each
other admiringly; for the most part, not even phone contact. When flirting
crosses the line--and it doesn't always--it's now romance.

In romance, the rules are no different on the 'Net than in real life (although I,
frankly, would use extreme caution when getting involved romantically on the
'Net). Full disclosure is mandatory before you transition from flirting to
dating.

We should be able to control that transition on the 'Net as well as we do in real
life (or better, I would hope). If you are comfortable, as a married black man,
flirting as a single blonde female wood elf, my only concern would be that you
maintain the relationships you initiate in exactly the fashion you started them.
I cannot stress enough that otherwise, by allowing the relationship to
transition, you are being deceitful. When you create a character with the intent
and purpose to 'become' that character for others, then you are only deceitful
when you stop being that character. If you commit to a certain personality, then
you are only deceitful when you stop being that personality.

> On the other hand, that 20-year-old boy is going to be way hurt if he EVER
> finds out. That's why I pick on people my own size, hehe, or as my cousin
> would say, 'He's below the legal limit! Throw 'em back!' But then, that's my
> take as a 30-year-old woman who shares her age with anyone. I have a few boys
> related to me that are very wounded now, and I just want to kill the women
> responsible because they knew full well what they were doing. Maybe I hold
> women to a higher standard, and maybe it's wrong, but I don't expect men to
> think of others because they're well, men, and I expect women to. <sigh> I
> apologize if I have offended.

Aelwesara, Povar
